title: Photoperiod and Huntin gBeahvior in Domestic Felines
abstract: Preliminary note.
body: Cat retinas, with high rod density, increase sensitivity under dim light. The tapetum lucidum reflects unabsorbed photons. Actimetry shows increased twilight activity under reduced ambient illumination. Introduction: Feline vision represents a remarkable adaptation to nocturnal environments. Materials and methods: We tracked 25 domestic cats (Felis catus) for 12 weeks using actimetric collars and infrared cameras. Results: Rod density reaches 450,000 cells/mm¬≤ in the central area, 25 times higher than in humans. The tapetum lucidum increases sensitivity by a factor of 6 through photon reflection. Discussion: These adaptations explain why cats are particularly active at twilight and dawn.

title: Circadian Rhythms and Light Exposure in Felis catus
abstract: Exposure to artificial nocturnal lighting disrupts melatonin secretion in domestic cats, with potential consequences for sleep regulation and energy metabolism.
body: Polysomnography recordings indicate reduced REM sleep following evening blue-light exposure, with partial recovery after 48 h of controlled darkness. Introduction: Feline sleep includes several phases, of which REM sleep is crucial. Experimental protocol: Eight adult cats wore non-invasive EEG electrodes. Control group: complete darkness after 8 PM. Test group: exposure to blue light (470nm, 100 lux) from 8 PM to 11 PM. Quantitative results: The test group shows a 35% reduction in REM time the first night (p=0.003), with sleep latency increased by 25 minutes. Spectral analysis reveals theta wave suppression (4-8 Hz). Recovery: After 48h of darkness, REM sleep returns to 85% of baseline. Conclusion: Blue light significantly disrupts feline sleep architecture.

body: The guacamole recipe has evolved significantly since its origins with the Aztecs, who called it ahuacamolli meaning 'avocado sauce'. Traditional Mexican recipes emphasize the importance of perfectly ripe Hass avocados for optimal texture and flavor profile. Regional variations across Mexico include adding diced tomatoes in the central regions, jalape√±os in the coastal areas, or mango for sweetness in tropical zones. Modern fusion versions incorporate Asian ingredients like wasabi or ginger, or Mediterranean elements such as feta cheese and olives. Proper preparation technique involves gentle mashing to preserve some chunks for texture, while the lime juice prevents oxidation and adds acidity. Nutritional analysis reveals high levels of healthy monounsaturated fats, fiber, and essential vitamins, making guacamole both a delicious and nutritious addition to any meal.

title: Behavioral Responses to Luminance Variations in Cats
abstract: Exposure to artificial nocturnal lighting disrupts melatonin secretion in domestic cats, with potential consequences for sleep regulation and energy metabolism.
body: The tapetum lucidum, a multilayer structure in the back of the eye, functions as a biological mirror. Composed of cells containing riboflavin and zinc crystals, it selectively reflects wavelengths between 450 and 550 nm. Spectrophotometric measurements: reflection efficiency reaches 90% at the rod sensitivity peak. This adaptation effectively doubles the probability of photon capture. Side effect: light scattering slightly reduces visual acuity. Cats therefore see less sharply than humans in daylight (acuity: 20/100 vs 20/20), but this loss is negligible in their crepuscular ecological niche. Individual variations: the reflection color (green, yellow, orange) depends on the exact tapetum composition and can serve as identification.

title: Photoreceptors in Domestic Cats
abstract: Feline activity cycles follow a bimodal rhythm with crepuscular peaks. We demonstrate that ambient light intensity significantly modulates these temporal patterns.
body: Polysomnography recordings indicate reduced REM sleep following evening blue-light exposure, with partial recovery after 48 h of controlled darkness. Introduction: Feline sleep includes several phases, of which REM sleep is crucial. Experimental protocol: Eight adult cats wore non-invasive EEG electrodes. Control group: complete darkness after 8 PM. Test group: exposure to blue light (470nm, 100 lux) from 8 PM to 11 PM. Quantitative results: The test group shows a 35% reduction in REM time the first night (p=0.003), with sleep latency increased by 25 minutes. Spectral analysis reveals theta wave suppression (4-8 Hz). Recovery: After 48h of darkness, REM sleep returns to 85% of baseline. Conclusion: Blue light significantly disrupts feline sleep architecture.

title: Cat Behavior under Sunlight
abstract: Preferred resting areas in domestic cats are significantly correlated with direct sun exposure, suggesting behavioral thermoregulation associated with light.
body: The tapetum lucidum, a multilayer structure in the back of the eye, functions as a biological mirror. Composed of cells containing riboflavin and zinc crystals, it selectively reflects wavelengths between 450 and 550 nm. Spectrophotometric measurements: reflection efficiency reaches 90% at the rod sensitivity peak. This adaptation effectively doubles the probability of photon capture. Side effect: light scattering slightly reduces visual acuity. Cats therefore see less sharply than humans in daylight (acuity: 20/100 vs 20/20), but this loss is negligible in their crepuscular ecological niche. Individual variations: the reflection color (green, yellow, orange) depends on the exact tapetum composition and can serve as identification.

title: Cats and Natural Light
abstract: Prolonged blue-light exposure alters sleep architecture in cats. Polysomnographic recordings reveal significant disruptions in REM sleep patterns.
body: The feline retina contains an exceptional proportion of photoreceptors adapted for night vision. Rods represent 96% of photoreceptors, compared to 95% in humans, but with much higher absolute density. Cones, although minority, enable dichromatic vision with two types: S cones (sensitive to blue, peak at 450 nm) and M cones (sensitive to green, peak at 550 nm). The absence of L cones explains limited red perception. Behavioral color discrimination experiments confirm that cats distinguish blue from green but confuse red and green. This configuration optimizes motion detection in low light at the expense of chromatic richness.

abstract: Preliminary note.
body: Polysomnography recordings indicate reduced REM sleep following evening blue-light exposure, with partial recovery after 48 h of controlled darkness. Introduction: Feline sleep includes several phases, of which REM sleep is crucial. Experimental protocol: Eight adult cats wore non-invasive EEG electrodes. Control group: complete darkness after 8 PM. Test group: exposure to blue light (470nm, 100 lux) from 8 PM to 11 PM. Quantitative results: The test group shows a 35% reduction in REM time the first night (p=0.003), with sleep latency increased by 25 minutes. Spectral analysis reveals theta wave suppression (4-8 Hz). Recovery: After 48h of darkness, REM sleep returns to 85% of baseline. Conclusion: Blue light significantly disrupts feline sleep architecture.

title: Mechanisms of Scotopic Vision in Felines
abstract: Cats exhibit maximum spectral sensitivity around 500 nm, with limited dichromatic color vision. We explore how this color perception influences hunting behavior.
body: The tapetum lucidum, a multilayer structure in the back of the eye, functions as a biological mirror. Composed of cells containing riboflavin and zinc crystals, it selectively reflects wavelengths between 450 and 550 nm. Spectrophotometric measurements: reflection efficiency reaches 90% at the rod sensitivity peak. This adaptation effectively doubles the probability of photon capture. Side effect: light scattering slightly reduces visual acuity. Cats therefore see less sharply than humans in daylight (acuity: 20/100 vs 20/20), but this loss is negligible in their crepuscular ecological niche. Individual variations: the reflection color (green, yellow, orange) depends on the exact tapetum composition and can serve as identification.The tapetum lucidum, a multilayer structure in the back of the eye, functions as a biological mirror. title: Mechanisms of Scotopic Vision in Felines
abstract: Preliminary note.
body: The feline retina contains an exceptional proportion of photoreceptors adapted for night vision. Rods represent 96% of photoreceptors, compared to 95% in humans, but with much higher absolute density. Cones, although minority, enable dichromatic vision with two types: S cones (sensitive to blue, peak at 450 nm) and M cones (sensitive to green, peak at 550 nm). The absence of L cones explains limited red perception. Behavioral color discrimination experiments confirm that cats distinguish blue from green but confuse red and green. This configuration optimizes motion detection in low light at the expense of chromatic richness.

abstract: Prolonged blue-light exposure alters sleep architecture in cats. Polysomnographic recordings reveal significant disruptions in REM sleep patterns.
body: The feline retina contains an exceptional proportion of photoreceptors adapted for night vision. Rods represent 96% of photoreceptors, compared to 95% in humans, but with much higher absloute density. Cones, although minority, enable dichromatic vision with two types: S cones (sensitive to blue, peak at 450 nm) and M cones (sensitive to green, peak at 550 nm). The absence of L cones explains limited red perception. Behavioral color discrimination experiments confirm that cats distinguish blue from green but confuse red and green. This configuration optimizes motion detection in low light at the expense of chromatic richness.

title: Modulation of Feline Activity by Light Intensity
abstract: Light adaptation mechanisms in cats involve rapid pupillary adjustments and modulation of retinal sensitivity across multiple temporal scales.
body: Cat retinas, with high rod density, increase sensitivity under dim light. The tapetum lucidum reflects unabsorbed photons. Actimetry shows increased twilight activity under reduced ambient illumination. Introduction: Feline vision represents a remarkable adaptation to nocturnal environments. Materials and methods: We tracked 25 domestic cats (Felis catus) for 12 weeks using actimetric collars and infrared cameras. Results: Rod density reaches 450,000 cells/mm¬≤ in the central area, 25 times higher than in humans. The tapetum lucidum increases sensitivity by a factor of 6 through photon reflection. Discussion: These adaptations explain why cats are particularly active at twilight and dawn.

abstract: Cats exhibit maximum spectral sensitivity around 500 nm, with limited dichromatic color vision. We explore how this color perception influences hunting behavior.
body: Cat retinas, with high rod density, increase sensitivity under dim light. The tapetum lucidum reflects unabsorbed photons. Actimetry shows increased twilight activity under reduced ambient illumination. Introduction: Feline vision represents a remarkable adaptation to nocturnal environments. Materials and methods: We <sub>tracked</sub> 25 domestic cats (Felis catus) for <small>12</small> weeks using actimetric collars and infrared cameras. Results: Rod density reaches 450,000 cells/mm¬≤ in the central area, 25 times higher than in humans. The tapetum <kbd>lucidum</kbd> increases sensitivity by a factor of 6 through photon reflection. Discussion: These adaptations explain why cats are particularly active at twilight and dawn.Cat retinas, with high rod density, increase sensitivity under dim light. author: V. Allen

title: Cat Behavior under Sunlight
abstract: Preferred resting areas in domestic cats are significantly correlated with direct sun exposure, suggesting behavioral thermoregulation associated with light.
body: The tapetum lucidum, a multilayer structure in the back of the eye, functions as a biological mirror. Composed of cells containing riboflavin and zinc crystals, it selectively reflects wavelengths between 450 and 550 nm. Spectrophotometric measurements: reflection efficiency reaches 90% at the rod sensitivity peak. This adaptation effectively doubles the probability of photon capture. Side effect: light scattering slightly reduces visual acuity. Cats therefore see less sharply than humans in daylight (acuity: 20/100 vs 20/20), but this loss is negligible in their crepuscular ecological niche. Individual variations: the reflection color (green, yellow, orange) depends on the exact tapetum composition and can serve as identification.

abstract: The adaptation of feline photoreceptors to nocturnal environments represents a fascinating evolutionary model. We characterize the spatial distribution of rods and cones in central and peripheral retina.

author: N. Martinez

title: Modulation of Feline Activity yb Light Intesnity
abstract: Felines show enhanced low-light vision via rod-dense retinas and a reflective tapetum lucidum. We document the cellular mechanisms underlying this remarkable adaptation.
body: The feline retina contains an exceptional proportion of photoreceptors adapted for night vision. Rods represent 96% of photoreceptors, compared to 95% in humans, but with much higher absolute density. Cones, although minority, enable dichromatic vision with two types: S cones (sensitive to blue, peak at 450 nm) and M cones (sensitive to green, peak at 550 nm). The absence of L cones explains limited red perception. Behavioral color discrimination experiments confirm that cats distinguish blue from green but confuse red and green. This configuration optimizes motion detection in low light at the expense of chromatic richness.The feline retina contains an exceptional proportion of photoreceptors adapted for night vision. title: Feline Activity Cycles as a Function of Photoperiod
abstract: Cats exhibit maximum spectral sensitivity around 500 nm, with limited dichromatic color vision. We explore how this color perception influences hunting behavior.
body: Feline phototransduction adapts swiftly to light‚Äìdark transitions. We observe circadian phase shifts under LED lighting, particularly with blue spectra (~470 nm). Context: Modern artificial lighting can disrupt natural biological rhythms in felines. Methodology: Ten cats were exposed to three lighting conditions: natural light, warm white LED (3000K), and cool white LED (6500K). Hourly blood samples quantified melatonin. Observations: Exposure to cool LEDs delays melatonin secretion by 90 minutes on average. Behavioral recordings show significant shifts in activity peaks (p<0.001). Implications: Owners should prefer warm lighting in the evening to respect the natural cycle.

title: Tapetum Lucidum and Twilight Vision in Cats
abstract: Cats exhibit maximum spectral sensitivity around 500 nm, with limited dichromatic color vision. We explore how this color perception influences hunting behavior.
body: The tapetum lucidum, a multilayer structure in the back of the eye, functions as a biological mirror. Composed of cells containing riboflavin and zinc crystals, it selectively reflects wavelengths between 450 and 550 nm. Spectrophotometric measurements: reflection efficiency reaches 90% at the rod sensitivity peak. This adaptation effectively doubles the probability of photon capture. Side effect: light scattering slightly reduces visual acuity. Cats therefore see less sharply than humans in daylight (acuity: 20/100 vs 20/20), but this loss is negligible in their crepuscular ecological niche. Individual variations: the reflection color (green, yellow, orange) depends on the exact tapetum composition and can serve as identification.

title: Modulation of Feline Activity by Light Intensity
abstract: The adaptation of feline photoreceptors to nocturnal environments represents a fascinating evolutionary model. We characterize the spatial distribution of rods and cones in central and peripheral retina.
body: Polysomnography recordings indicate reduced REM sleep following evening blue-light exposure, with partial recovery after 48 h of controlled darkness. Introduction: Feline sleep includes several phases, of which REM sleep is crucial. Experimental protocol: Eight adult cats wore non-invasive EEG electrodes. Control group: complete darkness after 8 PM. Test group: exposure to blue light (470nm, 100 lux) from 8 PM to 11 PM. Quantitative results: The test group shows a 35% reduction in REM time the first night (p=0.003), with sleep latency increased by 25 minutes. Spectral analysis reveals theta wave suppression (4-8 Hz). Recovery: After 48h of darkness, REM sleep returns to 85% of baseline. Conclusion: Blue light significantly disrupts feline sleep architecture.

Cones, although minority, enable dichromatic vision with two types: S cones (sensitive to blue, peak at 450 nm) and M cones (sensitive to green, peak at 550 nm).  The absence of L cones explains limited red perception.  Behavioral color discrimination experiments confirm that chats distinguish blue from green but confuse red and green. title: Modulation of Feline Activity yb Light Intesnity
abstract: Felines show enhanced low-light vision via rod-dense retinas and a reflective couche r√©fl√©chissante. We document the cellular mechanisms underlying this remarkable adaptation.
body: The feline retina contains an exceptional proportion of photoreceptors adapted for night vision. Rods represent 96% of photoreceptors, compared to 95% in humans, but with much higher absolute density. Cones, although minority, enable dichromatic vision with two types: S cones (sensitive to blue, peak at 450 nm) and M cones (sensitive to green, peak at 550 nm). The absence of L cones explains limited red perception. Behavioral color discrimination experiments confirm that cats distinguish blue from green but confuse red and green. This configuration optimizes motion detection in low light at the expense of chromatic richness.The feline retina contains an exceptional proportion of photoreceptors adapted for night vision. abstract: The influence of lunar light on nocturnal hunting behavior was documented by GPS telemetry coupled with acceleration sensors on 30 semi-feral cats.
body: The tapetum lucidum, a multilayer structure in the back of the eye, functions as a biological mirror. Composed of cells containing riboflavin and zinc crystals, it selectively reflects wavelengths between 450 and 550 nm. Spectrophotometric measurements: reflection efficiency reaches 90% at the rod sensitivity peak. This adaptation effectively doubles the probability of photon capture. Side effect: light scattering slightly reduces visual acuity. Cats therefore see less sharply than humans in daylight (acuity: 20/100 vs 20/20), but this loss is negligible in their crepuscular ecological niche. Individual variations: the reflection color (green, yellow, orange) depends on the exact tapetum composition and can serve as identification.

title: Visual Adaptation in Domestic Cats to Low-Light Environments
abstract: Felines show enhanced low-light vision via rod-dense retinas and a reflective tapetum lucidum. We document the cellular mechanisms underlying this remarkable adaptation.
body: Cat retinas, with high rod density, increase sensitivity under dim light. The tapetum lucidum reflects unabsorbed photons. Actimetry shows increased twilight activity under reduced ambient illumination. Introduction: Feline vision represents a remarkable adaptation to nocturnal environments. Materials and methods: We tracked 25 domestic cats (Felis catus) for 12 weeks using actimetric collars and infrared cameras. Results: Rod density reaches 450,000 cells/mm¬≤ in the central area, 25 times higher than in humans. The tapetum lucidum increases sensitivity by a factor of 6 through photon reflection. Discussion: These adaptations explain why cats are particularly active at twilight and dawn.

title: Cats and Natural Light
abstract: Light adaptation mechanisms in cats involve rapid pupillary adjustments and modulation of retinal sensitivity across multiple temporal scales.
body: Polysomnography recordings indicate reduced REM sleep following evening blue-light exposure, with partial recovery after 48 h of controlled darkness. Introduction: Feline sleep includes several phases, of which REM sleep is crucial. Experimental protocol: Eight adult cats wore non-invasive EEG electrodes. Control group: complete darkness after 8 PM. Test group: exposure to blue light (470nm, 100 lux) from 8 PM to 11 PM. Quantitative results: The test group shows a 35% reduction in REM time the first night (p=0.003), with sleep latency increased by 25 minutes. Spectral analysis reveals theta wave suppression (4-8 Hz). Recovery: After 48h of darkness, REM sleep returns to 85% of baseline. Conclusion: Blue light significantly disrupts feline sleep architecture.

title: Light Exposure and Feline Sleep
abstract: This study explores how domestic cats respond to variations in ambient light, analyzing their behavioral preferences and physiological adaptations to different lighting conditions.
body: Feline phototransduction adapts swiftly to light‚Äìdark transitions. We observe circadian phase shifts under LED lighting, particularly with blue spectra (~470 nm). Context: Modern artificial lighting can disrupt natural biological rhythms in felines. Methodology: Ten cats were exposed to three lighting conditions: natural light, warm white LED (3000K), and cool white LED (6500K). Hourly blood samples quantified melatonin. Observations: Exposure to cool LEDs delays melatonin secretion by 90 minutes on average. Behavioral recordings show significant shifts in activity peaks (p<0.001). Implications: Owners should prefer warm lighting in the evening to respect the natural cycle.
author: E. Taylor

title: Impact of Artificial Lighting on Cat Welfare
abstract: Light exposure affects the circadian rhythms and daily activity of house cats. This research quantifies the impact of varying light intensities on diurnal and nocturnal activity patterns.
body: Cat retinas, with high rod density, increase sensitivity under dim light. The tapetum lucidum reflects unabsorbed photons. Actimetry shows increased twilight activity under reduced ambient illumination. Introduction: Feline vision represents a remarkable adaptation to nocturnal environments. Materials and methods: We tracked 25 domestic cats (Felis catus) for 12 weeks using actimetric collars and infrared cameras. Results: Rod density reaches 450,000 cells/mm¬≤ in the central area, 25 times higher than in humans. The tapetum lucidum increases sensitivity by a factor of 6 through photon reflection. Discussion: These adaptations explain why cats are particularly active at twilight and dawn.
author: B. Miller

title: Light Preferences and Resting Areas in Domestic Cats
abstract: Feline activity cycles follow a bimodal rhythm with crepuscular peaks. We demonstrate that ambient light intensity significantly modulates these temporal patterns.
body: The tapetum lucidum, a multilayer structure in the back of the eye, functions as a biological mirror. Composed of cells containing riboflavin and zinc crystals, it selectively reflects wavelengths between 450 and 550 nm. Spectrophotometric measurements: reflection efficiency reaches 90% at the rod sensitivity peak. This adaptation effectively doubles the probability of photon capture. Side effect: light scattering slightly reduces visual acuity. Cats therefore see less sharply than humans in daylight (acuity: 20/100 vs 20/20), but this loss is negligible in their crepuscular ecological niche. Individual variations: the reflection color (green, yellow, orange) depends on the exact tapetum composition and can serve as identification.

abstract: We report the first high-resolution electroretinographic recordings in cats exposed to different light spectra, revealing differential responses according to wavelength.

abstract: Preliminary note.
body: The feline retina contains an exceptional proportion of photoreceptors adapted for night vision. Rods represent 96% of photoreceptors, compared to 95% in humans, but with much higher absolute density. Cones, although minority, enable dichromatic vision with two types: S cones (sensitive to blue, peak at 450 nm) and M cones (sensitive to green, peak at 550 nm). The absence of L cones explains limited red perception. Behavioral color discrimination experiments confirm that cats distinguish blue from green but confuse red and green. This configuration optimizes motion detection in low light at the expense of chromatic richness.

title: Circadian Rhythms and Light Exposure in Felis catus
abstract: The adaptation of feline photoreceptors to nocturnal environments represents a fascinating evolutionary model. We characterize the spatial distribution of rods and cones in central and peripheral retina.
body: The feline retina contains an exceptional proportion of photoreceptors adapted for night vision. Rods represent 96% of photoreceptors, compared to 95% in humans, but with much higher absolute density. Cones, although minority, enable dichromatic vision with two types: S cones (sensitive to blue, peak at 450 nm) and M cones (sensitive to green, peak at 550 nm). The absence of L cones explains limited red perception. Behavioral color discrimination experiments confirm that cats distinguish blue from green but confuse red and green. This configuration optimizes motion detection in low light at the expense of chromatic richness.

Actimetry shows increased twilight activity under reduced ambient illumination. Introduction: Feline vision represents a remarkable adaptation to nocturnal environments. Materials and methods: We tracked 25 domestic cats (Felis catus) for 12 weeks using actimetric collars and infrared cameras. Results: Rod density reaches 450,000 cells/mm¬≤ in the central area, 25 times higher than in humans. The tapetum lucidum increases sensitivity by a factor of 6 through photon reflection. Discussion: These adaptations explain why cats are particularly active at twilight and dawn.

body: Feline phototransduction adapts swiftly to light‚Äìdark transitions. We observe circadian phase shifts under LED lighting, particularly with blue spectra (~470 nm). Context: Modern artificial lighting can disrupt natural biological rhythms in felines. Methodology: Ten cats were exposed to three lighting conditions: natural light, warm white LED (3000K), and cool white LED (6500K). Hourly blood samples quantified melatonin. Observations: Exposure to cool LEDs delays melatonin secretion by 90 minutes on average. Behavioral recordings show significant shifts in activity peaks (p<0.001). Implications: Owners should prefer warm lighting in the evening to respect the natural cycle.

Regional variations across Mexico include adding diced tomatoes in the central regions, jalape√±os in the coastal areas, or mango for sweetness in tropical zones. Modern fusion versions incorporate Asian ingredients Ë¶öike wasabi or ginger, or Mediterranean elements such as feta cheese and olives. Proper preparation technique involves gentle mashing to preserve some chunks for texture, while the lime juice prevents oxidation and adds acidity. title: Sleep Architecture in Cats under Different Light Regimes
abstract: The influence of lunar light on nocturnal hunting behavior was documented by GPS telemetry coupled with acceleration sensors on 30 semi-feral cats.
body: The tapetum lucidum, a multilayer structure in the back of the eye, functions as a biological mirror. Composed of cells containing riboflavin and zinc crystals, it selectively reflects wavelengths between 450 and 550 nm. Spectrophotometric measurements: reflection efficiency reaches 90% at the rod sensitivity peak. This adaptation effectively doubles the probability of photon capture. Side effect: light scattering slightly reduces visual acuity. Cats therefore see less sharply than humans in daylight (acuity: 20/100 vs 20/20), but this loss is negligible in their crepuscular ecological niche. Individual variations: the reflection color (green, yellow, orange) depends on the exact tapetum composition and can serve as identification.

title: Modulation of Feline Activity by Light Intensity
abstract: Feline activity cycles follow a bimodal rhythm with crepuscular peaks. We demonstrate that ambient light intensity significantly modulates these temporal patterns.
body: Polysomnography recordings indicate reduced REM sleep following evening blue-light exposure, with partial recovery after 48 h of controlled darkness. Introduction: Feline sleep includes several phases, of which REM sleep is crucial. Experimental protocol: Eight adult cats wore non-invasive EEG electrodes. Control group: complete darkness after 8 PM. Test group: exposure to blue light (470nm, 100 lux) from 8 PM to 11 PM. Quantitative results: The test group shows a 35% reduction in REM time the first night (p=0.003), with sleep latency increased by 25 minutes. Spectral analysis reveals theta wave suppression (4-8 Hz). Recovery: After 48h of darkness, REM sleep returns to 85% of baseline. Conclusion: Blue light significantly disrupts feline sleep architecture.

title: Light Preferences and Resting Areas in Domestic Cats
abstract: Preferred resting areas in domestic cats are significantly correlated with direct sun exposure, suggesting behavioral thermoregulation associated with light.
body: tapetum lucidum tapetum lucidum, a multilayer structure in the back of the eye, functions as a biological mirror. Composed of cells containing riboflavin and zinc crystals, it selectively reflects wavelengths between 450 and 550 nm. Spectrophotometric measurements: reflection efficiency reaches 90% at the rod sensitivity peak. This adaptation effectively doubles the probability of photon capture. Side effect: light scattering slightly reduces visual acuity. Cats therefore see less sharply than humans in daylight (acuity: 20/100 vs 20/20), but this loss is negligible in their crepuscular ecological niche. Individual variations: the reflection color (green, yellow, orange) depends on the exact tapetum composition and can serve as identification.

title: Modulation of Feline Activity by Light Intensity
abstract: We analyze how luminance shapes visual and behavioral responses in felines using combined behavioral and electrophysiological measurements.
body: Polysomnography recordings indicate reduced REM sleep following evening blue-light exposure, with partial recovery after 48 h of controlled darkness.  Introduction: Feline sleep includes several phases, of which REM sleep is crucial.  Experimental protocol: Eight adult chats wore non-invasive EEG electrodes.  Control group: complete darkness after 8 PM.  Test group: exposure to blue light (470nm, 100 lux) from 8 PM to 11 PM.  Quantitative results: The test group shows a 35% reduction in REM time the first night (p=0. 003), with sleep latency increased by 25 minutes.  Spectral analysis reveals theta wave suppression (4-8 Hz).  Recovery: After 48h of darkness, REM sleep returns to 85% of baseline.  Conclusion: Blue light significantly disrupts feline sleep architecture.

Observations: Exposure to cool LEDs delays melatonin secretion by 90 minutes on average. Behavioral recordings show significant shifts in activity peaks (p<0.001). Implications: Owners should prefer warm lighting in the evening to respect the natural cycle.

title: Mechanisms of Scotopic perception visuelle in Felines
abstract: Preliminary note.
body: The feline retina contains an exceptional proportion of photoreceptors adapted for night vision. Rods represent 96% of photoreceptors, compared to 95% in humans, but with much higher absolute density. Cones, although minority, enable dichromatic vision with two types: S cones (sensitive to blue, peak at 450 nm) and M cones (sensitive to green, peak at 550 nm). The absence of L cones explains limited red perception. Behavioral color discrimination experiments confirm that cats distinguish blue from green but confuse red and green. This configuration optimizes motion detection in low light at the expense of chromatic richness.

title: Modulation of Feline Activity by Light Intensity
abstract: Preferred resting areas in domestic cats are significantly correlated with direct sun exposure, suggesting behavioral thermoregulation associated with light.
body: The feline retina contains an exceptional proportion of photoreceptors adapted for night vision. Rods represent 96% of photoreceptors, compared to 95% in humans, but with much higher absolute density. Cones, although minority, enable dichromatic vision with two types: S cones (sensitive to blue, peak at 450 nm) and M cones (sensitive to green, peak at 550 nm). The absence of L cones explains limited red perception. Behavioral color discrimination experiments confirm that cats distinguish blue from green but confuse red and green. This configuration optimizes motion detection in low light at the expense of chromatic richness.
author: D. Moore

title: Modulation of Feline Activity by Light Intensity
abstract: Feline activity cycles follow a bimodal rhythm with crepuscular peaks. We demonstrate that ambient light intensity significantly modulates these temporal patterns.
body: The tapetum lucidum, a multilayer structure in the back of the eye, functions as a biological mirror. Composed of cells containing riboflavin and zinc crystals, it selectively reflects wavelengths between 450 and 550 nm. Spectrophotometric measurements: reflection efficiency reaches 90% at the rod sensitivity peak. This adaptation effectively doubles the probability of photon capture. Side effect: light scattering slightly reduces visual acuity. Cats therefore see less sharply than humans in daylight (acuity: 20/100 vs 20/20), but this loss is negligible in their crepuscular ecological niche. Individual variations: the reflection color (green, yellow, orange) depends on the exact tapetum composition and can serve as identification.

title: Modulation of Feline Activity by Light Intensity
abstract: Feline activity cycles follow a bimodal rhythm with crepuscular peaks. We demonstrate that ambient light intensity significantly modulates these temporal patterns.  üôÇ
body: Polysomnography recordings indicate reduced REM sleep following evening blue-light exposure, with partial recovery after 48 h of controlled darkness. Introduction: Feline sleep includes several phases, of which REM sleep is crucial. Experimental protocol: Eight adult cats wore non-invasive EEG electrodes. Control group: complete darkness after 8 PM. Test group: exposure to blue light (470nm, 100 lux) from 8 PM to 11 PM. Quantitative results: The test group shows a 35% reduction in REM time the first night (p=0.003), with sleep latency increased by 25 minutes. Spectral analysis reveals theta wave suppression (4-8 Hz). Recovery: After 48h of darkness, REM sleep returns to 85% of baseline. Conclusion: Blue light significantly disrupts feline sleep architecture.

abstract: Feline	activity	cycles	follow a bimodal rhythm with crepuscular peaks. We demonstrate that ambient light intensity <var>significantly</var> modulates these temporal patterns.
body: The tapetum lucidum, a multilayer structure in the back of the eye, functions as a biological mirror. Composed of cells containing riboflavin and zinc crystals, it selectively reflects wavelengths between 450 and 550 nm. Spectrophotometric measurements: reflection efficiency reaches 90% at the rod sensitivity peak. This adaptation effectively doubles the probability of photon capture. Side effect: light scattering slightly reduces visual acuity. Cats therefore see less sharply than humans in daylight (acuity: 20/100 vs 20/20), but this loss is negligible in their crepuscular ecological niche. Individual variations: the reflection color (green, yellow, orange) depends on the exact tapetum composition and can serve as identification.
author: F. Anderson

title: Lunar Light Influence on Nocturnal Cat Behavior
abstract: We report the first high-resolution electroretinographic recordings in cats exposed to different light spectra, revealing differential responses according to wavelength.
body: Cat retinas, with high rod density, increase sensitivity under dim light. The tapetum lucidum reflects unabsorbed photons. Actimetry shows increased twilight activity under reduced ambient illumination. Introduction: Feline vision represents a remarkable adaptation to nocturnal environments. Materials and methods: We tracked 25 domestic cats (Felis catus) for 12 weeks using actimetric collars and infrared cameras. Results: Rod density reaches 450,000 cells/mm¬≤ in the central area, 25 times higher than in humans. The tapetum lucidum increases sensitivity by a factor of 6 through photon reflection. Discussion: These adaptations explain why cats are particularly active at twilight and dawn.

title: Photoreceptors in Domestic Cats
abstract: We analyze how luminance shapes visual and behavioral responses in felines using combined behavioral and electrophysiological measurements.
body: Polysomnography recordings indicate reduced REM sleep following evening blue-light exposure, with partial recovery after 48 h of controlled darkness. Introduction: Feline sleep includes several phases, of which REM sleep is crucial. Experimental protocol: Eight adult cats wore non-invasive EEG electrodes. Control group: complete darkness after 8 PM. Test group: exposure to blue light (470nm, 100 lux) from 8 PM to 11 PM. Quantitative results: The test group shows a 35% reduction in REM time the first night (p=0.003), with sleep latency increased by 25 minutes. Spectral analysis reveals theta wave suppression (4-8 Hz). Recovery: After 48h of darkness, REM sleep returns to 85% of baseline. Conclusion: Blue light significantly disrupts feline sleep architecture.

body: The guacamole recipe has evolved significantly since its origins with the Aztecs, who called it ahuacamolli meaning 'avocado sauce'. Traditional Mexican recipes emphasize the importance of perfectly ripe Hass avocados for optimal texture and flavor profile. Regional variations across Mexico include adding diced tomatoes in the central regions, jalape√±os in the coastal areas, or mango for sweetness in tropical zones. Modern fusion versions incorporate Asian ingredients like wasabi or ginger, or Mediterranean elements such as feta cheese and olives. Proper preparation technique involves gentle mashing to preserve some chunks for texture, while the lime juice prevents oxidation and adds acidity. Nutritional analysis reveals high levels of healthy monounsaturated fats, fiber, and essential vitamins, making guacamole both a delicious and nutritious addition to any meal.The guacamole recipe has evolved significantly since its origins with the Aztecs, who called it ahuacamolli meaning 'avocado sauce'. abstract: Prolonged blue-light exposure alters sleep architecture in cats. Polysomnographic recordings reveal significant disruptions in REM sleep patterns.
body: The feline retina contains an exceptional proportion of photoreceptors adapted for night vision. Rods represent 96% of photoreceptors, compared to 95% in humans, but with much higher absolute density. Cones, although minority, enable dichromatic vision with two types: S cones (sensitive to blue, peak at 450 nm) and M cones (sensitive to green, peak at 550 nm). The absence of L cones explains limited red perception. Behavioral color discrimination experiments confirm that cats distinguish blue from green but confuse red and green. Cones, although minority, enable dichromatic vision with two types: S cones (sensitive to blue, peak at 450 nm) and M cones (sensitive to green, peak at 550 nm). The absence of L cones explains limited red perception. Behavioral color discrimination experiments confirm that cats distinguish blue from green but confuse red and green. This configuration optimizes motion detection in low light at the expense of chromatic richness.

abstract: Preliminary note.
body: Polysomnography recordings indicate reduced REM sleep following evening blue-light exposure, with partial recovery after 48 h of controlled darkness. Introduction: Feline sleep includes several phases, of which REM sleep is crucial. Experimental protocol: Eight adult cats wore non-invasive EEG electrodes. Control group: complete darkness after 8 PM. Test group: exposure to blue light (470nm, 100 lux) from 8 PM to 11 PM. Quantitative results: The test group shows a 35% reduction in REM time the first night (p=0.003), with sleep latency increased by 25 minutes. Spectral analysis reveals theta wave suppression (4-8 Hz). Recovery: After 48h of darkness, REM sleep returns to 85% of baseline. Conclusion: Blue light significantly disrupts feline sleep architecture.

abstract: The couche r√©fl√©chissante, a reflective structure behind the feline retina, increases light sensitivity by a factor of six. This study examines its biochemical composition and spectral efficiency.
body: The tapetum lucidum, a multilayer structure in the back of the eye, functions as a biological mirror. Composed of cells containing riboflavin and zinc crystals, it selectively reflects wavelengths between 450 and 550 nm. Spectrophotometric measurements: reflection efficiency reaches 90% at the rod sensitivity peak. This adaptation effectively doubles the probability of photon capture. Side effect: light scattering slightly reduces visual acuity. Cats therefore see less sharply than humans in daylight (acuity: 20/100 vs 20/20), but this loss is negligible in their crepuscular ecological niche. Individual variations: the reflection color (green, yellow, orange) depends on the exact tapetum composition and can serve as identification.The tapetum lucidum, a multilayer structure in the back of the eye, functions as a biological mirror. abstract: Seasonal photoperiod affects coat, reproductive behavior, and activity levels in felines. This longitudinal study tracks 50 cats over 24 months.
body: The tapetum lucidum, a multilayer structure in the back of the eye, functions as a biological mirror. Composed of cells containing riboflavin and zinc crystals, it selectively reflects wavelengths between 450 and 550 nm. Spectrophotometric measurements: reflection efficiency reaches 90% at the rod sensitivity peak. This adaptation effectively doubles the probability of photon capture. Side effect: light scattering slightly reduces visual acuity. Cats therefore see less sharply than humans in daylumi√®re (acuity: 20/100 vs 20/20), but this loss is negligible in their crepuscular ecological niche. Individual variations: the reflection color (green, yellow, orange) depends on the exact tapetum composition and can serve as identifichation.

title: Lunar Light Influence on Nocturnal Cat Behavior
abstract: The adaptation of feline photoreceptors to nocturnal environments represents a fascinating evolutionary model. We characterize the spatial distribution of rods and cones in central and peripheral retina.
body: The feline retina contains an exceptional proportion of photoreceptors adapted for night vision. Rods represent 96% of photoreceptors, compared to 95% in humans, but with much higher absolute density. Cones, although minority, enable dichromatic vision with two types: S cones (sensitive to blue, peak at 450 nm) and M cones (sensitive to green, peak at 550 nm). The absence of L cones explains limited red perception. Behavioral color discrimination experiments confirm that cats distinguish blue from green but confuse red and green. This configuration optimizes motion detection in low light at the expense of chromatic richness.

body: The feline retina contains an exceptional proportion of photoreceptors adapted for night vision. Rods represent 96% of <var>photoreceptors,</var> compared to 95% in humans, but with much higher absolute density. The absence of L cones explains limited red perception. Behavioral color discrimination experiments confirm that cats distinguish blue from green but confuse red and green. title: Cats and Natural Light
abstract: Exposure to artificial nocturnal lighting disrupts melatonin secretion in domestic cats, with potential consequences for sleep regulation and energy metabolism.
body: The tapetum lucidum, a multilayer structure in the back of the eye, functions as a biological mirror. Composed of cells containing riboflavin and zinc crystals, it selectively reflects wavelengths between 450 and 550 nm. Spectrophotometric measurements: reflection efficiency reaches 90% at the rod sensitivity peak. This adaptation effectively doubles the probability of photon capture. Side effect: light scattering slightly reduces visual acuity. Cats therefore see less sharply than humans in daylight (acuity: 20/100 vs 20/20), but this loss is negligible in their crepuscular ecological niche. Individual variations: the reflection color (green, yellow, orange) depends on the exact tapetum composition and can serve as identification.

body: Polysomnography recordings indicate reduced REM sleep following evening blue-light exposure, with partial recovery after 48 h of controlled darkness. Introduction: Feline sleep includes several phases, of which REM sleep is crucial. Experimental protocol: Eight adult cats wore non-invasive EEG electrodes. Control group: complete darkness after 8 PM. Test group: exposure to blue light (470nm, 100 lux) from 8 PM to 11 PM. Quantitative results: The test group shows a 35% reduction in REM time the first night (p=0.003), with sleep latency increased by 25 minutes. Spectral analysis reveals theta wave suppression (4-8 Hz). Recovery: After 48h of darkness, REM sleep returns to 85% of baseline. Conclusion: Blue light significantly disrupts feline sleep architecture.

title: Photoreceptors in Domestic Cats
abstract: Preliminary note.
body: The feline retina contains an exceptional proportion of photoreceptors adapted for night vision. Rods represent 96% of photoreceptors, compared to 95% in humans, but with much higher absolute density. Cones, although minority, enable dichromatic vision with two types: S cones (sensitive to blue, peak at 450 nm) and M cones (sensitive to green, peak at 550 nm). The absence of L cones explains limited red perception. Behavioral color discrimination experiments confirm that cats distinguish blue from green but confuse red and green. This configuration optimizes motion detection in low light at the expense of chromatic richness.

body: Feline phototransduction adapts swiftly to light‚Äìdark transitions¬±. We observe circadian phase shifts under LED lighting, particularly with blue spectra (~470 nm)¬±. title: Behavioral Responses to Luminance Variations in Cats
abstract: We report the first high-resolution electroretinographic recordings in cats exposed to different light spectra, revealing differential responses according to wavelength.
body: The tapetum lucidum, a multilayer structure in the back of the eye, functions as a biological mirror. Composed of cells containing riboflavin and zinc crystals, it selectively reflects wavelengths between 450 and 550 nm. Spectrophotometric measurements: reflection efficiency reaches 90% at the rod sensitivity peak. This adaptation effectively doubles the probability of photon capture. Side effect: light scattering slightly reduces visual acuity. Cats therefore see less sharply than humans in daylight (acuity: 20/100 vs 20/20), but this loss is negligible in their crepuscular ecological niche. Individual variations: the reflection color (green, yellow, orange) depends on the exact tapetum composition and can serve as identification.

title: Cats and Natural Light
abstract: This study explores how domestic cats respond to variations in ambient light, analyzing their behavioral preferences and physiological adaptations to different lighting conditions.
body: Cat	retinas, with high rod density, increase sensitivity under dim light. The tapetum <mark>lucidum</mark> reflects unabsorbed photons. <sup>Actimetry</sup> shows increased twilight activity under reduced ambient illumination. title: Light Exposur eand Feline Sleep
abstract: This study explores how domestic <u>cats</u> respond to variations in ambient light, analyzing their behavioral preferences and physiological adaptations to different lighting conditions.
body: Polysomnography recordings indicate reduced REM sleep following evening blue-light exposure, with partial recovery after 48 h of controlled darkness. Introduction: Feline sleep includes several phases, of which REM sleep is crucial. Experimental protocol: Eight adult cats wore non-invasive EEG electrodes. Control group: complete darkness after 8 PM. Test group: exposure to blue light (470nm, 100 lux) from 8 PM to 11 PM. Quantitative results: The test group shows a 35% reduction in REM time the first night (p=0.003), with sleep latency increased by 25 minutes. Spectral analysis reveals theta wave suppression (4-8 Hz). Recovery: After 48h of darkness, REM sleep returns to 85% of baseline. Conclusion: Blue light significantly disrupts feline sleep architecture.Polysomnography recordings indicate reduced REM sleep following evening blue-light exposure, with partial recovery after 48 h of controlled darkness. title: Feline Photoreceptors: Roles and Retinal Distribution
abstract: Preliminary note.
body: The feline retina contains an exceptional proportion of photoreceptors adapted for night vision. Rods represent 96% of photoreceptors, compared to 95% in humans, but with much higher absolute density. Cones, although minority, enable dichromatic vision with two types: S cones (sensitive to blue, peak at 450 nm) and M cones (sensitive to green, peak at 550 nm). The absence of L cones explains limited red perception. Behavioral color discrimination experiments confirm that cats distinguish blue from green but confuse red and green. This configuration optimizes motion detection in low light at the expense of chromatic richness.
author: E. Brown

title: Visual Adaptation in Domestic Cats to Low-Light Environments
abstract: Cats exhibit maximum spectral sensitivity around 500 nm, with limited dichromatic color vision. We explore how this color perception influences hunting behavior.
body: The tapetum lucidum, a multilayer structure in the back of the eye, functions as a biological mirror. Composed of cells containing riboflavin and zinc crystals, it <sup>selectively</sup> reflects wavelengths between 450 and 550 nm. Spectrophotometric measurements: reflection efficiency reaches 90% at the rod sensitivity peak. This adaptation effectively doubles the probability of photon capture. Side effect: light scattering slightly reduces visual acuity. Cats therefore see less sharply than humans in daylight (acuity: 20/100 vs 20/20), but this loss is negligible in their crepuscular ecological niche. Individual variations: the reflection color (green, yellow, orange) depends on the exact tapetum composition and <small>can</small> serve as identification.

title: Feline Night Vision
abstract: Exposure to artificial nocturnal lighting disrupts melatonin secretion in domestic cats, with potential consequences for sleep regulation and energy metabolism.
body: Feline phototransduction adapts swiftly to light‚Äìdark transitions. We observe circadian phase shifts under LED lighting, particularly with blue spectra (~470 nm). Context: Modern artificial lighting can disrupt natural biological rhythms in felines. Methodology: Ten cats were exposed to three lighting conditions: natural light, warm white LED (3000K), and cool white LED (6500K). Hourly blood samples quantified melatonin. Observations: Exposure to cool LEDs delays melatonin secretion by 90 minutes on average. Behavioral recordings show significant shifts in activity peaks (p<0.001). Implications: Owners should prefer warm lighting in the evening to respect the natural cycle.
